overview: Leviticus, the book of holiness, provides detailed instructions for Israel's worship, sacrifices, and daily living. It reveals how a holy God can dwell among sinful people through atonement and consecration.

verses.text: Speak to all the congregation of the people of Israel and say to them, You shall be holy, for I the LORD your God am holy.
For the life of the flesh is in the blood, and I have given it for you on the altar to make atonement for your souls, for it is the blood that makes atonement by the life.
You shall not take vengeance or bear a grudge against the sons of your own people, but you shall love your neighbor as yourself: I am the LORD.

passages.title: The Day of Atonement
passages.summary: The annual day when the high priest entered the Most Holy Place to make atonement for Israel's sins, foreshadowing Christ's ultimate sacrifice.

passages.title: The Holiness Code
passages.summary: Practical instructions for holy living, including the command to love your neighbor—later quoted by Jesus as the second greatest commandment.

facts.text: The word 'holy' appears more times in Leviticus than in any other book of the Bible—over 90 times.
The five main offerings (burnt, grain, peace, sin, guilt) each picture different aspects of Christ's sacrifice.
Jesus quoted Leviticus 19:18 ('love your neighbor') as the second greatest commandment (Matthew 22:39).
The scapegoat on the Day of Atonement symbolically carried away the people's sins—a vivid picture of what Christ does for believers.

figures.name: Aaron
figures.description: Israel's first high priest, consecrated in Leviticus 8-9 to serve as mediator between God and the people in the tabernacle.

figures.name: Nadab and Abihu
figures.description: Aaron's sons who offered unauthorized fire before the Lord and were struck dead—a sobering warning about approaching God carelessly.

videos.title: Leviticus Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explains how Leviticus reveals the path to living in God's holy presence.
